item.title: Modeling Change
item.description: Introduction A mathematical model is an idealization of the real-world phenomenon, which will never be completely accurate.

item.title: The Modeling Process, Proportionality, and Geometric Similarity
item.description: Modeling Procedure Observe real-world behavior and simplify factors Conjecture relationships among factors and create rough model Use mathmatical analysis to conclude the model Interpret mathematical conclusions in terms of the real-world problem Conclusions pertain only to the model not real-world ...

item.title: HiMCM & MidMCM
item.description: COMAP’S High School Mathematical Contest in Modeling (HiMCM) and Middle Mathematical Contest in Modeling (MidMCM) are international contests designed to provide high school and middle school/level students with the opportunity to work as team members to engage and improve their modeling, problem sol...

item.title: MCM & ICM
item.description: COMAP’s Mathematical Contest in Modeling (MCM) and Interdisciplinary Contest in Modeling (ICM) are international contests for high school students and college undergraduates.

item.title: Experimental Modeling
item.description: One-Term Models A One-Term Model describle the quantity changes over time using a single mathmatical term or expression.

item.title: Game Theory
item.description: Outcome depends on only one player is called decision theory. Outcome depends on two or more players is called game theory.

item.title: Modeling Using Graph Theory
item.description: The Seven Bridges of Königsberg The Seven Bridges of Königsberg is a famous historical problem, posed in the city of Königsberg (now Kaliningrad, Russia).

item.title: Modeling with Decision Theory
item.description: Probability and Expected Value \text{probability of an event = } \frac {\text{favorable outcomes}} {\text{total outcomes}} Weighted Average The formula of expected value is: E = w_1 p_1 + w_2 p_2 + \cdots + w_n p_n or E = \sum_{i=1}^{n} w_i p_i where w_i is the payoff of each outcome, p_i (0 \leq p_...

item.title: Optimization of Discrete Models
item.description: The basic model is: \text{Optimize } f_j(\mathbf{X}) \quad \text{for } j \in J \text{subject to } \quad g_i(\mathbf{X}) \begin{cases} \geq b_i \\ = b_i \\ \leq b_i \end{cases} \quad \text{for all } i \in I In the formula, to optimize means to maximize or minimize.
